definitions.definition: very stupid; not at all sensible

examples.text: You **must be mad** to risk it.
It was a mad idea.
‘I'm going to buy some new clothes.’ ‘Well, don't **go mad** *(= spend more than is sensible)*.’
You'd **be raving mad** to miss this annual music extravaganza.

definitions.definition: having a mental illness that makes somebody unable to think or behave normally

examples.text: Inventors are not mad scientists.
I'll **go mad** if I have to wait much longer.
She seemed to have gone **stark raving mad**.
His experiences in the First World War drove him mad.
The local people all thought she was mad.

definitions.sensetop: mad at/with somebody (for doing something)mad about something
definitions.labels: (especially North American English, informal)(British English)(British English)especially North American Englishespecially British English

examples.text: He **got mad** and walked out.
She's mad at me for being late.
They're pretty mad about being lied to.
That noise is **driving me mad**.
He'll **go mad** when he sees the damage.
I get so mad when people don't take me seriously.
It makes me really mad when people waste food.
My mum's absolutely mad with me!
Please don't be mad with me!
Dad'll go mad when he sees what you've done.

definitions.definition: liking something/somebody very much; very interested in something
definitions.sensetop: mad about something/somebodymad on something/somebodymad for something/somebody

examples.text: He's always been mad about music.
to be mad on tennis
Scott's mad for peanuts.
football-mad boys
She's completely power-mad.
He's absolutely mad about cars.
She's really mad about painting.

definitions.definition: done without thought or control; wild and excited

examples.text: The crowd made a **mad rush** for the exit.
Only a **mad dash** got them to the meeting on time.
The four companies are in a **mad scramble** for market share.
The team won and the fans **went mad**.
to be **mad with anger/excitement/grief/jealousy/love/power**
I went mad with joy and danced a little jig.
She was nearly bitten by a mad dog.
Love him or hate him, the man's got mad skills.
I have to give **mad props** *(= proper respect)* to the camera team.
I had to run like mad to catch the bus.

definitions.definition: with crazy ideas or behaviour; very silly
liking something/somebody very much; very interested in something

examples.text: He's mad keen on planes.

wordOrigin: Old English gemǣd(e)d ‘maddened’, participial form related to gemād ‘mad’, of Germanic origin.
